portfolio-sidebar.question: Why I design technology, you ask...
portfolio-sidebar.answer: started with a desire to explore science and technology, I begin to dive into making it. Soon after, I realize before making technology I have to learn designing technology considering people who will be using it. It changed my perspective about how I used to design atechnology driven experience, from a technology centric design to human centric design. Now it's a passion!

about.intro:
You may have heard of computer scientist, programmer, visual designer, experience designer, interface designer and even design technologist, but what the heck is "wildcard"?

It's someone, none of the above, Or, all of the above! Someone who knows their stuff inside and out, but still keeps an open mind. Someone who posses a big bag of tricks in variety of areas, but always keen to learn. Someone who is curious and not afraid of the unexpected but embraces it and thrive on it. Someone who is facinated by different perspectives.

synku-exploring-the-production-of-sensor.title: SynKu: Exploring the Production of Sensory Objects
synku-exploring-the-production-of-sensor.citation: Ankur Agrawal, Wenvi Hidayat, Aravind Ravi, Mark Stamnes, Meishen Yin, and Daniela Rosner. 2015. SynKu: Exploring the Production of Sensory Objects. In Proceedings of the 33rd Annual ACM Conference Extended Abstracts on Human Factors in Computing Systems (CHI EA '15). ACM, New York, NY, USA, 2121-2126. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1145/2702613.2732813
synku-exploring-the-production-of-sensor.abstract: This paper describes SynKu, a mobile application that merges audio and image processing with human interpretation to speculate on the production of sensory objects. Sensory objects are representations of sensory phenomena interpreted and used by both people and software. We discuss how the SynKu application enables us to explore how algorithms help to change and legitimate the reconstruction of sensory phenomena across self-tracking platforms.

designing-for-movement-in-public-life-wi.title: Designing for Movement in Public Life with Itinerant Probes
designing-for-movement-in-public-life-wi.citation: Daniela K. Rosner, Margaret E. Morris, Ariel Duncan, Sarah E. Fox, Kathi R. Kitner, Ankur Agrawal, and Mei J. Chen. 2016. Designing for Movement in Public Life with Itinerant Probes. In Proceedings of the 2016 ACM Conference on Designing Interactive Systems (DIS '16). ACM, New York, NY, USA, 1072-1082. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1145/2901790.2901913
designing-for-movement-in-public-life-wi.abstract: This pictorial illustrates how objects can illuminate people's experience of public space, an approach we call itinerant probes. Itinerant probes are not individualized, mediated artifacts, but instead dynamic events that en- liven people's personal and collective memories. Building on the probes literature and recent ecological perspectives, we describe three probes related to lighting that we investigated at three public sites. Our explorations with these probes highlight the intimate histories associated with public spaces.

cheetah-intel-labs.title: Cheetah
cheetah-intel-labs.description: During first 6 months of my employment at Intel Labs I was awarded Cheetah award for my effort to design and prototype an experience and help shape future direction for my organization inside Intel Labs.
